identificationModule.briefTitle: Surgeon Core-strengthening Program as a Modifier for Exertion Associated With Vaginal Surgery
identificationModule.officialTitle: Surgeon Core-strengthening Program as a Modifier for Exertion Associated With Vaginal Surgery: the SCORE Randomized Controlled Trial

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Work-related musculoskeletal pain and injury is a growing concern in surgery. Vaginal surgery has unique ergonomic risks, but no studies have addressed the potential for an exercise regimen to reduce physical strain by vaginal surgeons
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: Surgical ergonomics is a burgeoning field, spurred by the recognition of the high prevalence of work-related musculoskeletal pain and injury in practicing surgeons including obstetrician/gynecologists (Yurteri-Kaplan 2023 Obstet Gynecol). Surgery is often a demanding physical task, and the muscles and joints that are stressed vary by the surgical approach. Vaginal surgery has unique ergonomic challenges, particularly for assistants who may need to laterally bend their torsos to visualize the surgical field while still holding retractors. This is often a compromising physical position for the back, the shoulders, and sometimes the neck which increases the risk of acute or chronic musculoskeletal injury (Meltzer 2020 JAMA Surg). The risk of injury can be thought of as a discrepancy between the demands of the task and the individual's physical capabilities (Williams 2017 Occup Med (Lond)). Surgeons' injury risk may be decreased if their physical capabilities can be improved through exercise. Most existing publications on surgical ergonomics have focused on raising awareness and on environmental changes such as optimizing surgeon posture during the case or introducing micro-breaks and stretching (Meltzer 2020 JAMA Surg, Allespach 2020 J Surg Educ, Dairywala 2022 Semin Thoracic Surg, Winters 2020 Plast Reconstr Surg Glob Open). Few publications have assessed a structured exercise program with the goal of decreasing surgeon pain or fatigue during and after surgery (Giagio 2019 Ann Surg, Kopkash 2021 Ann Surg Oncol). To our knowledge, no studies have addressed this in vaginal surgery.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: The intervention group will complete a core workout lasting 20 minutes twice a week for 4 weeks

maskingInfo.maskingDescription: The control group will not have an exercise regimen. The PI will be blinded to randomization.

armGroups.label: Exercise Group
armGroups.description: Participants randomized to the exercise group will be asked to perform the SCORE workout two times each week for 4 weeks prior to their urogynecology rotation and for 4 weeks during the rotation.

armGroups.label: Control Group
armGroups.description: No additional exercises or tasks are requested of control participants. Control group participants will perform or not perform exercise as they otherwise would outside of the study

interventions.name: Execise Group
interventions.description: SCORE workout: eight exercises done sequentially: bicycles, balancing dog, windshield wipers, three-point plank, kayaker, super push-ups, bridge, and side plank. These workouts are modified from the core regimen recommended by Steve House and Scott Johnston in their book Training for the New Alpinism: A Manual for the Climber as Athlete (House 2014). Each exercise is done until fatigue: when the individual is no longer able to complete the exercise with good form. The participant then rests for approximately thirty to sixty seconds before beginning the next exercise. Passive stretching can be performed during the rest periods. The workout is complete at twenty minutes. Those individuals who complete all eight exercises in less than twenty minutes begin again with the first exercise (bicycles) and continue until reaching twenty minutes. The workout is thus adaptive-seamlessly increasing in repetitions as an individual's strength and endurance increase.

interventions.name: Control Group
interventions.description: No additional exercises or tasks are requested of control participants. Control group participants will perform or not perform exercise as they otherwise would outside of the study.

primaryOutcomes.measure: The effect of a core-strengthening program on surgeons' physical exertion during and after vaginal prolapse surgery using the Borg rating of perceived exertion (Borg CR10). To determine the effect of a core-strengthening program on surgeon
primaryOutcomes.description: Surgeons who complete a four-week core-strengthening program will have lower exertion scores during and immediately after vaginal prolapse surgery compared to those who do not complete the exercise program

secondaryOutcomes.measure: To compare vaginal surgeons' baseline core strength with a historical cohort of healthy volunteers using the validated Core Score.
secondaryOutcomes.description: Vaginal surgeons will have lower average core strength than healthy volunteers from the Core Score development cohort.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: To compare baseline exercise habits and activity level in a population of vaginal surgeons using activity tracker data and the International Physical Activity Questionnaire-Short Form (IPAQ-SF) with published cohorts of physicians
secondaryOutcomes.description: Vaginal surgeons will have a lower average physical activity level than published cohorts of international physicians.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: To measure the effect of a core-strengthening program on surgeons' pain during and after vaginal prolapse surgery using the PROMIS Pain Intensity-Short Form (PI-SF) and body diagrams.
secondaryOutcomes.description: Surgeons who complete the core-strengthening program will have lower pain scores than those who did not complete the program

secondaryOutcomes.measure: To measure objective and subjective change in core strength after completion of the core-strengthening program using the Core Score and Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I).
secondaryOutcomes.description: Surgeons who complete the core-strengthening program will have greater improvements in the Core Score and be more likely to report improvement in their sense of core strength.

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

Participant: ob/gyn resident or urology resident or urogyn fellow or urogyn attending Case: vaginal prolapse surgery \>2 hours in length

Exclusion Criteria:

Participant:

1. Actively in physical therapy
2. Joint surgery or joint injury within last 12 weeks
3. Pregnant
4. Less than 6 weeks postpartum

Case:

1. Vaginal surgery \<2 hours in length
2. Non-prolapse vaginal surgery
